text:
Sonia Sotomayor shares some of her family photos with NPR. And the story of a little girl from the Bronx, who made it all the way to the Supreme Court. 

Her life began in the tenements of the Bronx -- in a community of Puerto Rican immigrants.

transcript: This was the 1950s. You didn't leave your house in my mother's generation without your hair made up and makeup on.
There was a sense of pride in how you look. My family's standard of living was no different than the entire neighborhood.
I can't tell you how people afforded it. When I first moved to the projects, you did not walk into an apartment that wasn't clean and decent looking.

book_quote: "A tight few blocks in the South Bronx bounded the lives of my extended family: my grandmother matriarch of the tribe, her second husband, Gallego, her daughers and sons."

transcript: My mother will tell you today that I am my grandmother's daughter.
My grandmother was the most spirited person I've ever known.

She had boundless energy. Get up at the crack of dawn to make a pot of coffee for my grandfather. He drank it black and I drank it black. And we'd go out shopping. She'd come back and she'd start preparing food.
And that night there would be a party.
People would be playing dominos, they would be dancing.
They'd be singing; at some point in the evening the music would stop and I would know that the poetry would start.

text:
Chaos at home had to do with her father's alcoholism -- 

and her mother withdrawing in response.

transcript: I don't think I remember a warm moment between them. There may have been some but the overriding impression I had was that all they did was fight.

text: Still, Sotomayor has fond memories of her father.
transcript: He was enormously creative. He was a poet and loved poetry and recited it at parties with my grandmother.
I still remember some of his dishes. I don't think anyone has ever duplicated his liver and onions for me.

I can look at photos of him and I can tell you which photos were taken before he had really started drinking a lot and which photos he was already a little gone. You can see it in his eyes. And I often wondered about what he was thinking about.

It’s really hard to live with a person who has an addiction because their obsession with their addiction becomes the obsession of the family. There's internal torture in the people who are consumed by it.

So it seemed really strange to me that she couldn't stop crying after he died. We'd come home from school, she'd cook us dinner, and then she'd lock herself in the bedroom. And would leave early in the morning. And the pattern repeated itself day after day, week after week. After months of this I just couldn't stand it anymore.
I banged on her door, and I looked at her and said "are you going to die too? What is going to happen to Junior and me?  And I ran back into my bedroom, threw myself into my bed and cried.
My mother became a different woman. She began to really start nurtuing us as a mother. And I often talk of before daddy and after dady. Because my life was dramatically different thereafter.

The people we love the most are the people we get the angriest at. And it took me, and it has taken us -- my mother and I -- a lifetime to deal with the effects of my father's alcoholism on both of us.
Mom's early childhood was as poor as we could ever describe.  My aunt insisted that my mother be educated.

My mom gave me the same gift that my mom's sister gave her -- the gift of education. When dad died I began to read.  I had lost the desire to even play outside. The house was constantly dark. And reading became my rocketship out of the second floor apartment in the projects. That kind of learning is priceless. Books do that. Books open windows.

The first four years in school I was a marginal student. I was a C student, essentially. I knew words in English but at home spoke Spanish. I entered 5th grade and the teacher began to give out gold stars.
I wanted some of those gold stars. I found my competitive spirit. I had no idea that Harvard was an ivy league school. Even as the society has grown more sophisticated
I'm willing to bet there are still pockets of the "United States of Poverty" where there are kids who are as naive as I was then.
College wasn't a foregone conclusion back there. So it was a congratulatory moment for most people when you went to college.
But the level of excitement that people had that I had gotten into Princeton made me understand that something greater than the norm had happened.

text:
Sotomayor excelled at Princeton, and would go off to Yale Law School and the New York District Attorney's office, before becoming a judge.

But, she recalls, her two worlds would sometimes collide.

book_quote: "I could be yanked for a time into one world or the other, but mostly now I would be living suspended between the two."

transcript: I was never given permission to walk out on the streets by myself shopping. That wasn't true for Nelson. He was a boy and he was let out on the streets very early.
And at that time the South Bronx was Fort Apache -- the most crime ridden area in the nation, and he fell victim to drugs.
It's the scourge of many a poor neighborhood. And he was my dearest friend growing up. He took one road, I took another. And he died.

book_quote:
"How was it I had escaped when my soul's twin, my smarter half, once joined to me at the hip, had not?

Call it what you like: discipline, determination, perseverance, the force of will. ... If only I could bottle it, I'd share it with every kid in America. But where does it come from?"
